text: we as AWS have a tool called clout rail
also mentioned twice today but I think
this is this is very important because
clout rail is not monitoring some kind
of system locks but actually it's a it's
monitoring API calls
so everything what happens with data in
AWS is always an API call so if you
store your data files or whatever in in
in s3 so the this this the storage and
service and this data is accessed or
this data is removed or anything happens
with this file over this data this is
always a API call as well everything
what happens in databases that's always
an API call and the crowd trail is
actually logging all this information
and then you can use this logs and get
basically in real time meaningful
information out of this and I think this
is then actually really complying or
helping to comply with the requirements
of article 30 and I think a solution
like like this makes it much more easier
to comply with the regulation because I
said cloud trail is across all our
services so you we are not working in in
silos so that cloud trail for example is
is available for the one service but not
for the other service so if you are
thinking about moving workloads to the
cloud to AWS I think especially in the
area of access monitoring and processing
monitoring cloud trail is helping a lot
there's another tool called Amazon guard
duty Airport there are more tools and
I'm just picking out some of them and
guard duty is is a tool which is helping
to detect threats so this is more in the
area of unauthorized access to to to
data a tool which is also implemented
deeply in our services so it's not much
effort to configure it it's basically
turning it on and then guard duty is is
analyzing or monitoring your environment
so your resources on AWS
on on threats and of course you can
define alarms etc of course you can get
those data from cloud trail but as well
from guard duty out of the AWS platform
if you are planning to to use another
